tool.name: Unique lines
tool.command:
uniq #if $skipfields: -f $skipfields #end if $ignorecase
#if $grouping.grouping_select == 'yes': --group=$grouping.group #else: $grouping.count $grouping.repeated $grouping.uniqueonly #end if
"$infile"
#if $grouping.grouping_select == 'no' and $grouping.count: ## count will print the count with spaces in front of the line and ## with a space (not a tab) after the number, we need to cahnge that | sed -e 's/ *//' -e 's/ /\t/' #end if > "$outfile"

param.name: infile
param.label: File to scan for unique values
param.help: Make sure you have sorted this file

param.name: grouping_select
param.label: Do you want to group each unique group?

param.name: count
param.label: Counting number of occurrences
param.help: Prefix lines by the number of occurrences. (-c)

param.name: group
param.label: Output all lines, and delimit each unique group
param.option: Separate unique groups with a single delimiter
Output a delimiter before each group of unique items
Output a delimiter after each group of unique items
Output a delimiter around each group of unique items

param.name: ignorecase
param.label: Ignore differences in case when comparing

param.name: skipfields
param.label: Avoid comparing the first N fields
param.help: Use zero to start from the first field. (-f)

tool.help:
This tool takes a sorted file and look for lines that are unique.
.. class:: warningmark
Please make sure your file is sorted, or else this tool will give you an erroneous output.
.. class:: infomark
You can sort your file using either the "Sort" tool in "Filter and Sort", or the "Sort" tool in "Unix Tools".
@REFERENCES@
